item.title: Tidy Tuesday Extra - Bring Your Own Data
item.description: For this 53rd Tuesday in 2019, #TidyTuesday is a byod (bring-your-own-data) special. For this week, I’ll take a look at one of the weeks I missed from earlier in 2019. I’m only a few years removed from my grad school days, so government spending on R&D is an interest of mine. Week 7 it is: Federal R&D Spending. This is a very short post, but I have family in town, so I don’t wan tot go too far down a rabbit hole.

item.title: Tidy Tuesday 52 - Christmas Songs
item.description: This week’s #TidyTuesday is fittingly about Christmas songs. The clean version of the data comes from Kaggle. Data Import As always, we’ll start with data import, and I’ll use the tidytuesdayR package. library(tidyverse) library(ggthemes) dat <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2019, week = 52) lyrics <- dat$christmas_lyrics songs <- dat $christmas_songs Songs I’ll start by summarising some of the data. I’ll add three stats in this step: Total number of songs put out by the performer(s) Length the artist’s song spent on the billboard top 100 Quality score for the song defined as the sum of the normalized “rank” of the song.

item.description: Here is my entry for #TidyTuesday from 2019-50: ‘You can make it in R.’ Import the Data library(tidyverse) library(gganimate) library(waffle) d <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2019, week = 50) diseases <- d$diseases murders <- d$international_murders guns <- d$gun_murders regents <- d$nyc_regents Part 1: Diseases The first plot was inspired by an interactive graphic from WSJ. The data for these visuals comes from the Tycho Project. To start, let’s add a column that provides a rate of disease incidence.
